chapter.title: Developer Install and Setup
chapter.para: This chapter is designed to provide simple step-by-step instructions on how to set up a development machine to begin working with Kuali Rice on Mac OS X or Windows platforms with a MySQL database.

The steps to install and setup a developer machine with Kuali Rice are:
Database setup - Please refer to the Installing and Configuring the Database Management System section of this guide to install and configure your database.
Install & configure required software - Please refer to the Common Setup section of this guide to install and configure software required by both development and standalone server environments.
Set up your Development Environment
Install and Configure Rice
Launch the Sample Application

section.title: Development Environment
section.para: Eclipse is the open source Java Integrated Development Environment (IDE) that most Kuali application developers use and setup for Eclipse is outlined here. Another popular IDE used by some Kuali developers is IntelliJ IDEA. Instructions here will be for Eclipse.

section.title: Eclipse installation
section.para: Download the latest version of Eclipse from the eclipse.org download page:
Once you have downloaded the zip file, unzip it to a location of your choosing. Inside of that directory will be an executable named "eclipse" that you can use to start Eclipse.

section.title: Defining a Workspace
section.para: When Eclipse starts up for the first time it will ask you to identify a workspace to use. Enter a location of your choosing for your workspace. All of the projects that you check out from source control will be imported into that workspace.

section.title: Verify that Eclipse is Using Java 6
section.para: To verify that Eclipse is using Java 6, you will need to open the Eclipse "Preferences" pane. You do this on Windows by going to "Edit -> Preferences". On Mac OS X you nativate to "Eclipse -> Preferences".
Once on the Preferences pane, navigate to "Java -> Installed JREs". Ensure that Java 6 (or 1.6) is selected. See screenshot below:

section.title: Disable DTD, JSP, TagLib, and XML Validators
section.para:
The Kuali Rice code has some XML and Tag libraries with schemas and DTDs that do not validate well when being built inside of Eclipse. To eliminate Eclipse build errors, please disable these.
Open the Eclipse "Preferences" window.
Navigate to "Validation".
Deselect the following checkboxes under "Build".
DTD Validator
JSP Content Validator
JSP Syntax Validator
Tag Library Descriptor Validator
XML Schema Validator
XML Validator
XSL Validator
Click "OK.
When prompted to do a full rebuild, click "Yes".

section.title: Install Subclipse
section.para: Subclipse is a Subversion plugin for Eclipse. If you plan on checking out the Kuali Rice source code or any example code from the Kuali subversion repository, then it would be useful to install subclipse to manage this within Eclipse.

Subclipse is installed within Eclipse using Eclipse's update site feature with the following steps:
Click on the "Help" menu and select "Install New Software...".
This will open up the "Install" screen. Click on the "Add..." button.
This should bring up a dialog that allows you to add the Subclipse update site.
Type a name of "Subclipse" and a location like "http://subclipse.tigris.org/update_1.6.x" and click the "OK" button.
This will populate the Install screen with 3 different components that can be installed.
Check all three check boxes:
Click the "Next" button.
You should see the list of items that will be installed, click "Next" again.
On the "Review Licenses" screen, select "I accept the terms of the license agreements" and click the "Finish" button.
At this point Eclipse will begin downloading and installing Subclipse.
If you see a message that says "Warning: You are installing software that contains unsigned content", click "OK".
When asked to restart Eclipse, click "Restart Now".

section.title: Set up Eclipse for Maven
section.para:
In order to ensure that Eclipse can read from the Maven repository, we have to define the M2_REPO classpath variable:
Open your Eclipse "Preferences" screen.
Navigate to "Java -> Build Path -> Classpath Variables".
Click the "New..." button.
Create a new Classpath variable with the name of M2_REPO and a value pointing to your Maven repository directory (<user home/.m2/repository).
Click "Ok".
When prompted about a full rebuild, click "Yes".
